participants.participant: Michael Luscombe, Chief Executive Officer and Group Managing Director

plist.p: Okay, good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us. Apologies for the start being a little bit late. Questions of media went a little bit longer than we anticipated. Appreciate the fact that this is a very busy day for your community with Woolworths and Foster's and Rio and, I think, Suncorp all announcing, so we'll try and be as efficient as possible with the answers and with the presentation, because I know that there are more than Woolworths' fish to fry today.

Okay, last year has been yet another successful year for our business performing well across all of our divisions. We believe that it's because we have delivered consistently against the strategies that we defined each of our businesses and we put many years of hard work into building the foundation for that and that hard work has been not only our own staff and stores and the distribution centers and our support officers, but also the partnership that we have with our suppliers and our farmers. And lastly, of course, the growing confidence that consumers have in what was delivering great value in the marketplace.
Last year we invested pretty heavily in our businesses. We are going to continue to do that in 2009, but more particularly we believe that we are well positioned for future growth as a team.
The headline numbers, everybody has seen. I think a 24% EPS growth and a 25.7 growth in net profit after tax is a good result for the team for 2008.

Some of the highlights for the year. The investments that we made in our supermarkets with the refurbishments are being well received by our customers, not only are the comp numbers of customer counts increasing, but more particularly, we're getting stronger fresh food results. We're getting good margin mix changes in our non-fresh, and more importantly, the verbal reports that we're getting back through our focused groups has really indicated that we've hit the mark in terms of delivering either fresh and a really great venue offering to our customers. Last year we did 180 stores in the new format, up until about now – sorry, and a further 150 odd including 134 refurbishments are expected in the coming year.

We also launched the new logo for the Supermarkets at our Annual Conference last week. The stylized W is a harken back to one of our earlier chevrons that we had in the 70s and 80s with a fresh new look and obviously the lift at the top is the good link into the fresh food people. It has been remarkably received by our team, just as in the 80s and 90s and on for 21 years, the "Fresh Food People" banner was very much a rallying flag. This is really in a very short period of time, so planted that in the minds and hearts of our people, and I have the pleasure of going out to our store to have a look at this new brand in action at the store and it looked absolutely sensational about during the day, but at night with their new LED signage it really was a beacon, it looked absolutely fabulous.

Our Cards Program with Everyday Rewards has been very successful. Now just on 4 million cards out there, 2.5 million odd cards are registered, the vast majority of those registered online. And we now commenced new compensations with our customers in a way that wasn't possible before and new offers over and above the petrol offer that are being engineered through this card. It has been a terrific response from our customers, the feedback we've got in replacing the paper petrol dockets that we're forever getting lost or damaged or whatever being replaced by card has been very, very well received by our customers.

Later today, we are going to launch a credit card, Everyday Money, and the issuer is HSBC. We are very proud to have them there. They've obviously got other retail partners around the world and their scheme partner of course is MasterCard, a very widely accepted scheme right around the world.

You'll note that, it has very latest of safety including encryption involved in the physical benefits of the card. And it's going to be a card that has a very rich reward basically one point for every dollar that you spend outside of Woolies, two points for every dollar you spend inside the Woolworths Group and if you buy slick products three basis points or three points per dollar.

What we have seen then is that, we've attracted a number of families without trying to influence their behavior and looked at their spend on their credit card, both inside and outside of Woolworths, and on a quarterly basis without changing behavior and influencing behavior, we think that the average family will get – or a average credit card user will get about $70. But for those that regularly use their credit cards and do shop at Woolies not exclusively that actually goes up well over $100, so we can easily see people will be getting $500 worth of Everyday Money shopping cards per annum as a reward for shopping within the Woolworths Group. So very, very rich rewards.

And even one family that we checked at basically didn't use their credit card much, didn't shop at Woolies at all, still earned $30 enough to buy two kids outfits at BIG W. So this is very rich. The interest rate is at the low end at 18.99% presently, transferring balances 5.99%, special offer – carry-forward between now and February the 1st on all purchases, 0%; so Christmas shopping, back-to-school shopping, a great offer.

And the zero fee for applying in the first year and $49 thereafter, and a whole host of other things that we'll talk about a little bit later, that are part of a very rich but very affordable financial offering and we are the first of a number of offerings in this space. The team have done an absolutely outstanding job with their partners in delivering this product.

BIG W; the repositioning has continued extremely well. Seven quarters of positive sales growth. We've invested once again in price and maintained a very strong leadership in the price position in the marketplace. 16 stores refurbished, three the previous the year and a further 15 stores planned for refurbishment in the coming year.

Supply chain; we're continuing to get the benefits. The DCs that have been in place are well and truly delivering over and above their business case. Brisbane is in its commissioning year, is doing particularly well, of light, and we are about to – in fact we have started both DCs, so we're now in the receiving and spec stage in Sydney and Melbourne actually had its first receipt of stock yesterday.

In the near future, we'll talk about investments in distribution centers in Dick Smith and in BIG W and also a further Liquor DC in Queensland and further investment in DCs in New Zealand and we'll be announcing some investment in the Tasmanian marketplace to come. More importantly, the intellectual property that we've been able to get as a result of our experience in supermarkets has been well and truly leveraged across our other businesses.

Okay. The financial results; always good to look back over an extended period of time so here is the last year since the turn of the century and you can see that for each of our long-term strategic targets that we have managed to get ourselves a tick for the eighth year in a row or actually it's the ninth year in a row, isn't it?

Profit after taxes, we mentioned before, up 25.7 to 1.6 billion, a couple of one-offs there, obviously the 53rd week helped a little bit. We had some profit on sale of some real estate but even without that it was a good result by the team. CODB, for the first time we're under 20 basis points. It's always a strategic milestone for a business that is in the high-volume, low-margin business group they say it would be under 20%, we managed to do that and it's down 43 basis points. Obviously in that we've got the profit on the sale of certain properties and also the costs of both the Brisbane supply chain transition and also the establishment of the one – the credit card and also the petrol card. When we take both the positive and negatives out of that, it's still 38 basis points. And if we take out petrol and hotels – excuse me – it still is over 20 basis points. So a great result by the team.

Gross margin; we've got two numbers as we've decided to do going forward including and excluding hotels, and you can see that as a business we actually increased a little bit excluding our hotels – putting hotels back in, it's decreased a little bit by 2 basis points.

More importantly, what we would like to do is look back to 2004 and indicate despite the fact that we've actually improved our starting margin with private label, global sourcing, direct-to-store delivery, improvement in shrinkage, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera, we've taken over that period of time basically 100 basis points ahead of our gross margin delivering great value to our customers.
Dividends per share; we've announced 48-cent final dividend, so full year is 92, up 24.3%. The payout ratio is in line with previous year at 69%.

Supermarket division had a very strong result, team delivered great sales of 10.9. Gross margin was up just slightly four basis points, we put several $100 million into price reinvestment with getting to state based price groups and also some positions that we took on private label.

CODB down 32 basis points, which was a terrific result given the enormous number of refurbs that we did during the year. So the underlying cost of doing business reduction strip out the additional cost of the refurb program was just a fantastic effort.

So EBIT, the combination of two of those, 36 basis points improvement, and in dollar terms up 18.8. We're going to continue to reinvest in that business going forward. Inflation last year was 2.9, the previous year in '07 was 3.5; and we opened 30 new supermarkets.

Petrol; a really challenging year, three of the four quarters, prices significantly higher. The average motors actually went down probably in the region of 4 to 5%, on most weeks. Our comp sales increased by 11%, obviously reflecting the higher pump prices over the year. Our comp volumes in a market that was probably shrinking to have positive at 0.6, I think, was just a great reflection of the strength of our offer.

Our EBIT decreased by 1.2% to 81.9 million. EBIT margins were lower at 1.5% versus 1.7 . We actually made some strategic decisions at key times when petrol was going through $1.30, $1.40, $1.50 to hang on to the 0.98 of the earlier decile for as long as we could, so that we actually reestablished in the minds of the consumers that we really were understanding that this was a hard time for them, and wherever we could we hung on to that number for an extended period of time. The EBIT equates to 1.8 cents per liter sold, in 2007 it was 1.9 cents per liter.

More importantly, a little later this year, we've retrofitted all of our pumps with epump and for those cardholders who have new cards, they'll be able to drive into our service stations. They'll be able to wave the card, and it will recognize the fact that they are a cardholder. It will search the database to see what discounts that they've got available, you'll be able to fill up, and then you will just tap and then you'll go. The discount will be automatically applied to your petrol. We think that, particularly in our really, really busy service stations, having the ability to actually get people in and out quickly will be very, very well received and certainly help congestion at some of our key sites going forward.

We are very, very excited about this. We have been working on this for, probably best part of 18 months, may be even two years. So now that we have our card out there, we think this is going to be a real turbo charge to our petrol offer.

In Liquor, we had another great year in our three brands, Dan Murphy's, BWS and the Supermarket attached liquor, 4.7 billion, previous year 4.1. We now have over a thousand liquor outlets and, more importantly, within our business number of great strategies, one of them, of course, is with exclusive and control brands and private label, and I think one of the great examples of this is the recent launch of Platinum Blonde in July. We've had one of the major brewers come to us and ask how we manage to keep the taste in the low-carb beer because no one else has been able to do it and the sales of it has been – well, we actually ran out because we actually sold a lot more than we thought that we could to begin with.
Dan Murphy's has expanded its operations with another 22 stores, up to 89, and we have got the licenses and the sites to go to 155 within the next three years.

New Zealand Supermarkets. Tough time, particularly in the second half, sales up 7.3, gross margin, particularly with the introduction of private label has -- and global sourcing and a few other things that we have done, have improved by 10 basis points. CODB was tough. We had KiwiSaver and youth wages change in the marketplace. And we also, particularly in the second half and the last quarter in particular, ramped up tremendously our refurb program, so we had a lot of our big guns out of – well, under severe refurb there.

EBIT dropped by 4 basis points to 4.19 and the dollars were up by 6.5. More importantly, we are well on track to have finished all of our systems by about October this year, so that's our store system rollout, our AutostockR rollout, our merchandizing systems, where we replaced three legacy systems that we've been patching up and holding by their chinstraps for last couple of years. We can now decommission those. The Transport Management System, the Warehouse Management Systems, are on their way as well.

More importantly, we have decided on the way that we'll pay forward with our refurbs, so we've got a version of the 2010 that we are putting into New Zealand, and it's getting great customer reaction so far. Now we have to do – what we have to do is to ramp up dramatically. The Homebrand rollout is pretty much finished, we've got a few to go. We are now starting with Naytura, Select Organics, and Freefrom and our general merchandise, some range essentials that are being introduced, and once again they are being met with great customer acceptance.

BIG W had a terrific year, up 13%, gross margin up 19%. Clearly our mix changes and our global sourcing has helped in that area. Ramping up of the refurbs has certainly meant that a cost of doing business reduction was going to be challenging this year, but we believe it's a great investment for the future. EBIT, nonetheless, improved by 12 basis points and the dollar is up 16.3 – 16 as I mentioned before, and we opened nine new stores; very, very happy with the progress the team is making there.

Hotels; a challenging year with couple of things happening, the smoking bans in three states; and of course, in Victoria we had at Christmas time, a couple of hundred gaming machines had to go back. We finished with gaming comparable sales up 1.6% for the year, and our rating of what is available in the marketplace is that we're probably the only ones that actually had positive gaming comps, which is a terrific endorsement of the team. We finished the year with 271 hotels, nine additions during the year, including the Saturno Group in South Australia and probably most important is the gaming comparable sales in July, where we were very positive, so it was a good start to the year for hotels.

Consumer Electronics, up 11% for Australia and New Zealand. Gross margin, we invested in a very competitive marketplace. We also took the opportunity to mark down a lot of the ranges that are not going to be part of our strategy going forward, particularly in the bibs and bobs and small appliances and others that are not going to be part of our offer going forward and I'll say it'd be as we opened another 40-odd stores was a little challenging, and the EBIT to sales was down by 76 basis points. The combination of the two and EBIT was down by about $3 million to 68.1.

I think more importantly, we are on a new beginning with – along the same trial that we started the BIG W three years ago and the Supermarkets with the 2010c two years ago. This is the front of our new Hornsby Store, a couple of shots to really show the before and after. And you can see that from a customer experience point of view, it is like chalk and cheese, we've actually changed the range, highlighted a number of categories that are working really well. We've had tremendous sales growth in this particular store, whilst that centered Hornsby hasn't been traveling all that well. This store has been doing really well. A number of weeks we were 40% up on the previous year and other weeks where we've have been doing particularly well.

So in the next couple of weeks we're back to the board. We want to push the button on and we'll be asking for some capital to do that. And Debra and the team have certainly hit upon both from a financial point of view but more importantly from a customer reception point of view, a formula that will take us through in the medium-sized Dick Smith format.

Our business in India continues to grow. We have now got 22 opened. There is quite a few opening this year. The wholesale sales went from 25 to $104 million and as we planned, we've expensed all of our expansion of the DCs that we've opened during the year. And that has made a loss of $5 million. We will continue to expense rather than capitalize on any of the expenditure in India going forward.
I'll now ask Tom to come up and quickly take us through some of the more of the numbers and I'll join you for some follow-up comments.

Thanks Mike. Good morning, everyone. I'll just take you through some of the aspects of our balance sheet and cash flow for the year and comment on capital management. Our balance sheet overall remains very strong and in this current financial environment, I think it's a great asset for Woolworths to have going forward.

Some of the key features; our net investment in inventory was down about $330 million. Our fixed assets and investments were up about $1 billion, which is really the accelerated CapEx offset by depreciation. And we manage to repay just under $300 million in debt during the period and that's reflected in a lower interest cost that we could over the 12-month period. So a very strong position.

Our cash flow, our EBITDA is up about just under 18%. Our cash after interest and tax is up just on 24% which is very strong. After working capital, we're up about 16% and clearly the kick we got in working capital last year is not as great as the kick we got – or the kick we got this year is not as great as kick we got last year but still the 16% is very good increase. $2.6 billion in cash. We spent about $1.7 billion in CapEx as planned, so a very strong result and as I said $300 million repayment in debt.

Our inventory days down 0.8, very close to our target of one day, which is our ongoing target. With the fluctuating retail market, one of the core skills Woolworths has got with its systems and its disciplines is being able to manage inventory through those retail cycles and I think that 0.8 day reduction is excellent outcome in the current trading environment. So that's a very strong outcome.

Shareholder payouts; we've paid – over the last eight years we've paid back about 5.7 billion to shareholders. And in terms of capital management, as many of you would know, we made our capital structure to ensure that we've got flexibility going forward not only to pursue acquisitions but also to pursue other growth opportunities that we have got just for our own development. With our credit ratings at A- with Standard & Poor's and A3 have been maintained, and that puts us in a really good position that if we need to raise debt going forward for growth opportunities then we can access those markets with reasonably good pricing when we . We previously advise the market in 2000 that we do some form of capital management in 2008. However, with basically the equity and the debt markets in quite a lot amount of turmoil right at this point in time, we have decided to defer that. And I think it's prudent to do that. There is no point re-gearing the balance sheet without having certainty as to the cost of debt that you're going to put on your balance sheet.

We will as always continually assess the share buyback or capital management activity but that will be again in the context of anything we do in terms of acquisitions or in the current capital market environment.

On the debt side, the U.S. markets are in turmoil, the banks have written off their $500 billion, the second re-impacts could get 1.3 trillion. So it's not the right time to get into the debt market to re-gear our balance sheet.
Return on funds employed up 31.4%. The return on equity is 28.9%, slight increase, and I'll hand back to Mike Luscombe for strategy and growth.

I just want to give some context to next piece. Project Refresh always had three stages; we talked about each of them in turn. Now, the first one was about reorganizing particularly the Supermarket business into one national business and selling off some of the businesses that was going forward and then tackling the profit and loss line by line and becoming a much more efficient business.

The second stage was Project Mercury which was developing of the system and logistical expertise within the Supermarket group, along with private label, and a few other initiatives that we had in global sourcing et cetera. And the third one was in fact leveraging that across our existing businesses other than Supermarkets, and of course seeing how that might be applied to other businesses that weren't part out of the Woolworths Group, at the moment.

So, in terms of what underpins our strategy for growth, we believe that we have got capability in supply chain that sits there with those in the world. We believe that we have very much a low cost culture and we believe also that we've got a tremendous depth of talent right through our business.

Interesting to note for the second year in a row our management turnover was around about 7 to 8%, and when you take out retirements due to age or ill health then we lost very few people in the last couple of years. We think that those strengths are able to be leveraged, both into our existing businesses to grow organically and also we are continually evaluating how we might grow the group through acquisition. However, we don't want to take away from the fact that our vision is obviously to concentrate in making sure our core business continues to be successful by focusing on all those elements of convenience and price and quality that are important, and why the Woolworths businesses continue to attract more and more customers through their doors.

Each of the businesses have clear strategies that they're following and they are very much about delivering growth. We have defined plans for space growth in all of our businesses, with confirmed new store and they actually don't in most cases – in fact the vast majority of cases – contain any cannibalization of material effect.

We believe, given our market share in all of our businesses, food in Australia about 31%, the rest less than 30, and in New Zealand, that we have an ability to continue to grow market share in all of our businesses. And I think it'll be fair to say that we've got a good record of growth both through the development of new categories, and if you have a look at BIG W for instance, we have introduced the optometry range of offers that are doing particularly well and we are going to roll that out; and of course, new businesses, and Thomas Dux is another good example, that we opened our second store in Paddington, the other week at Five Ways and it is being really, really well received by the local consumer.

And there is no doubt that given our scale and our reach that we believe that we can leverage that into our goods and services and I think the credit card and other services that will follow past the credit card, clearly leverages that distribution capability that we have. And we also believe that in each of our businesses we have many opportunities to invest in future growth.

We are in the early stages of evaluating opportunities internationally and today I won't be entertaining any questions as to geography or what particular businesses there may be. But clearly what we are going to do is we are going to be very careful, very prudent, when we do, we'll do it in a confident fashion, but these businesses have to be high volume low margin businesses, so very much nimble. They've got to be well managed and they have to meet the hurdles that we have for all investments. If they don't get the ticks then we won't be doing it. But we think it's a good time to be doing it and we've been doing it in a fashion for a number of years, and of course India and New Zealand are good examples of that, but we obviously believe that it's a good time now to be having a good look.

We will continue however to invest in price and range and quality within our existing businesses. And in the past year, we invested heavily in all of our businesses in improving our price position. In all of our businesses we will continue with private and control brand and we've just got a couple here for the Supermarkets, within all of our brands BIG W probably other than Petrol we will continue to develop and expand our private labels.

With our card that we have 'Everyday Rewards' cards and now with our 'Everyday Money' card we will have enormous enhancement availability to actually check behavior that can be compared to what we hear from customers as to their intentions through market research. And it is always interesting to listen to intent and then check through behavior, because it's actually behavior that you want to try and really hone in on in terms of your offering as a retailer.

We are going to continue to invest in our financial services capability. I'm very happy to say that we now have all the major banks through our switch. And for the first year of operation it operated at amazing speed, number of transactions per second, but more importantly, we had 100% uptime. So, the first time in the history of Woolies that I can remember. Christmas time, Easter time, all those big trading periods we didn't have the credit cards and the system go down because we weren't relying on the third party to do it. So we are very, very happy with our investment in both our people, but more importantly in the infrastructure we put behind our financial services.

We are going to continue the acceleration of the refurbishment activity in Supermarkets and BIG W and as I mentioned earlier, we are also – we'll add to that the Dick Smith stores in the 2009 year, subject to obviously the board approving that. And our CapEx for the coming year will be at around $1.9 billion.

Our global sourcing activity, we've tripled our volume year-on-year. We've now opened a Shanghai office and they cover the Greater Asian area; and in particular, we've moved into not for resale products so we're now getting equipments such as shopping trolleys and others direct from the source and we get both improvements and quality and of course the cost is somewhat better too.

We also believe as I mentioned earlier that we continue to have a wonderful opportunity to leverage the supply chain expertise that we have in the logistics group as part of our Supermarket offer into other parts of our business and we're doing exactly that.

The growth plans very similar; they haven't changed in terms of our space rollout for the next couple of years and our long-term targets remain unchanged. So, for those in the room, you are very, very familiar with our commitment for sales and EBIT and EPS and CODB and the maintenance of target of the credit ratings within two credit rating agencies. Of course the EPS one is subject to both acquisition and of course any capital management initiatives that may happen.

So, in terms of the sales and earnings guidance subject to the fact that discretionary spend obviously continues to be influenced by such things as inflation, fluctuating petrol prices, interest rates and lower confidence levels amongst consumers, our guidance is such that we expect sales for this year to be in the upper single digits. We expect that EBIT will continue to grow faster than sales and the net profit after tax is expected to grow in the range of 11 to 14% on a 52 on 52, or if you take the 52 on 53 then it will be 9 to 12.

To give you a feeling for how we're going after seven weeks, Australian food, liquor and petrol top line sales after seven weeks were up over 12% and the comps were up over 10. If I split that between food and liquor and petrol, food and liquor was up 8.5 and comp 6.4. So we're running ahead of the fourth quarter numbers. Petrol up 34 and 30% comp. New Zealand a little bit tougher, up 1% and 1.7 comp. BIG W, a great start, 17% and 10% comp. Consumer Electronics up 19.5 and just under 9% comp and Hotels up 2% and just below flat in terms of comp.

So important however that we don't take that seven weeks and extrapolate that across the year but what I am happy to say is that we've had a good start to the year. The team have worked particularly well. I believe in our businesses particularly in Food that we've grown our market share again and widened the gap on our competitor. In fact the numbers that I see absolutely tell me that.
So, with that I'm very happy to show a beautiful truck which is a Euro 5 design newest in the country but a great exhibition of our new Food logo.
So Tom and I would be happy to entertain questions. Thank you. Greg you got your hand up first.

I got one for Tom but obviously I'll address it to you. I'm sort of curious about the decision you're making on capital management? I think I just saw the fixed capital ratio of 2.9 up from 2.7. You appear to be over capitalized. You refer to the stress in the markets which we all acknowledge, yet you don't seem to have any debt rollover that would require immediate attention. So my question is saying like this, your "planetary initiatives" quoting myself by acquisitions surely buying the stock back at $26 would give you a better return than a project like that? And I'm making reference to the fact that you said on the one hand you don't want to go to the debt markets for a buyback but on the other hand you'd be happy to for an acquisition?

gearing in this period, Greg, I don't think is a smart thing. Other retailers have gone in the market and have come back with ridiculous debt costs. The market – there's two issues in raising debt, one is the price and two is the execution risk. So – and if you talk to anyone out of the U.S. debt markets and I've done a significant amount of work talking to all the investment banks that are sitting in the U.S. market, they're all saying if you don't have to go to the debt markets right now then don't go. So I think commercially it's a rational decision to sit and wait. But that doesn't mean as things stabilize we're not going to do capital management. I think capital management is something we've done before. And we'll very clearly do again to keep the balance sheet efficient. I'm just saying right now, is probably not the most prudent time to do it. But we've got the capacity; we've got the franking credits. It's not off the table at all. If the debt markets settle themselves out in six months time and we don't do anything else, it will be absolutely back on the agenda.

It'd be fair to say we've had lots of really good advice from the assembled scholars in the room and that's probably been 70%, don't do it and 30%, do it. So at this point in time our Board has determined that we'll just hold their products a little longer but that, as Tom said, that doesn't mean that we've ruled it out completely?
But that's one implication, you've wouldn't consider undertaking acquisition in the near term also?
Well, that might be the case but when we do it we'll do it for the right reasons and we'll do it in a way that benefits our shareholders.
Thank you.
Hey Shawn.
Hey Mike. Just in regards to food and liquor margins, you spoke about the level of price investment.
Yes.
You got four?
Yes.

I guess if we're looking forward we've got cost of doing business falling by 20 bps at least in regards to some supply chain projects. But when do we start to see a lack of gross margin expansion in terms of rollback benefits no longer coming through, private label penetration starting to moderate and your price investment act actually resulting in EBIT margin starting to be flat lying or possibly, even going down?
I don't see it in the immediate future that there's no doubt the rollbacks continue to work for us. We still got quite a way to go. We've got plans in private

label across all of our business, but in Supermarkets we still believe that there's plenty of room for more private label, not necessarily at the expense of branded product. But we just think that we can do a better job. We've actually made some more space available in our stores by being very, very smart, the way that we've arranged our general merchandise. So, we have actually generated some more space, lineal space in our stores over the last little while and we think that we've actually expanded a little bit but we've reserved room to come back in, with some more private label.

We've still got – with the direct store delivery we've got the BE conversion happening at the moment with the introduction of the new stores. We continue to actually do a lot better with our shrinkage control, and there's still opportunities to continue to do it. We still know that we can – we've still got a lot of product that comes from overseas that comes through third parties that we have the potential to do better on.

So, I would say for the next couple of years, on the growth side there's an opportunity to improve our gross margin. We've been very much dependent on what our view is how reinvestment and price will actually drive volume and there is no great signs to that, you just need to be in retail for a while to really understand that. What we did last year on an annualized basis was for Supermarkets line was a more than a couple of $100 million but on the parts of the year where those decisions came in it was less than 200 but well above 150. And then, of course, we invested in Dick Smith because we had to become a lot more competitive. We invested in BIG W to maintain the gap on others in the marketplace. We invested in petrol because we thought it was a good thing and we certainly invested in price in New Zealand. So, we will continue to do that, but we will continue always to look at ways we can improve our margin and there are 93 ways that you can do that and I've just mentioned probably about five or six, but there are a lot more that can...
In regards to the supply chain, is there a substantial way through...
Yes.
how long do you continue to get cost out in your food and liquor business on a supply chain basis?

It will continue to improve – as each DC gets more mature, they just become – they get into a rhythm and they just become more and more efficient. So, the ones that we've finished for two or more years are now actually ahead of what we have projected to do and all credit to Julie and the team for doing that. Brisbane was a big – it was the biggest one we had to do and it's now heading towards its business case on schedule to hit its business case.

We got our two liquor DCs that we're opening and another one that will open in Queensland, and we also will announce an investment in Tasmania in due course that will bring us into the 21st century there, because we're – got 1960s at the moment, maybe not even that in Tasmania, but I mean we've got fantastic team there, but we really haven't given them the facilities that they need to be really efficient.
Okay, and in regards to New Zealand Supermarkets, I mean, have you lost market share in New Zealand?
